Introduction

Acute otitis media (AOM) is a bacterial infection of a middle ear effusion.  AOM can occur at any age but is most common in infants and young children.

Pathogenesis

The middle ear is connected to the nasopharynx via the eustachian tube.  AOM occurs when otopathogens enter the middle ear and proliferate, progressing to suppuration.  Several events typically precede the development of AOM:

  • The patient has an underlying event (eg, viral upper respiratory infection, allergen exposure) that triggers an inflammatory response within the nasal respiratory mucosa, causing edema.
  • Because the eustachian tube is also lined by respiratory mucosa, the inflammatory edema extends to this area, causing obstruction (
    figure 1
    ).
  • The obstruction causes poor ventilation and negative pressure in the middle ear.
  • This contributes to the accumulation of secretions that are normally produced by the middle ear mucosa, providing a rich medium for bacterial growth.
  • Pathogens that colonize the nasopharynx (eg, Streptococcus pneumoniae, nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae, Moraxella catarrhalis) ascend to the middle ear, leading to proliferation and suppuration.

Risk factors

  • Age <2:  The rate is particularly high between 6 and 12 months of age, likely due to the eustachian tube being shorter and more horizontal in young children (
    figure 2
    ), which hinders fluid drainage when compared to the longer, more vertical tubes in adults.
  • Day care attendance:  Children who attend day care centers contract frequent viral upper respiratory tract infections that cause inflammatory edema of the respiratory mucosa.
  • Tobacco smoke exposure:  Patients exposed to tobacco smoke appear to have increased colonization of the nasopharynx with otopathogens.
  • Family history:  This may be related to heritable anatomic or immunologic features that predispose to AOM.

Of note, breastfed infants are less likely to develop AOM, likely due to the relative decrease in bacterial colonization of the nasopharynx and/or the immunologic benefits of breast milk.

The development of AOM is uncommon in adults; risk factors for this patient population include eustachian tube dysfunction and/or obstruction leading to poor ventilation, negative pressure in the middle ear, and immune dysfunction.

Clinical presentation

Otalgia, which may manifest as ear pulling in young children, is the most common symptom of AOM in children and adults but is not always present.  Fever occurs in up to two-thirds of patients.  Young infants often have the nonspecific signs and symptoms of irritability, poor sleep, and decreased appetite.  Examination shows middle ear effusion with signs of acute inflammation (eg, bulging of the tympanic membrane [TM] (

figure 3
)).  In some cases, pressure from suppuration may cause the TM to rupture, resulting in otorrhea with sudden relief of otalgia.

Diagnosis

AOM is a clinical diagnosis that requires a thorough history and physical examination with otoscopy.  Diagnostic criteria for AOM requires the presence of a middle ear effusion and middle ear inflammation, as follows:

  • Middle ear effusion:  A middle ear effusion can be visualized as bubbles or air-fluid levels behind the TM.  If no bubbles or air-fluid levels are present, a middle ear effusion can be confirmed by the presence of â‰¥2 of the following features: abnormal color (eg, white, yellow), impaired mobility (ie, via pneumatic insufflation or visualization of a bulging TM), or opacity of the TM.
  • Middle ear inflammation:  Middle ear inflammation can be represented by bulging (the most specific sign of acute middle ear inflammation), bullae (
    figure 4
    ), or marked erythema of the TM.  Of note, TM erythema is nonspecific (eg, occurs due to vascular engorgement from crying) and must be accompanied by bulging or impaired mobility to diagnose AOM.

Clinical diagnosis may also be made if purulent otorrhea is visualized in the external ear canal due to a rupture of the TM (

Otitis media
).  Culture and sensitivities of middle ear fluid are not necessary but may be considered in severe, recurrent, or chronic cases or in immunocompromised or postoperative patients.

Differential diagnosis

  • Otitis media with effusion (OME):  In contrast to AOM, OME is a middle ear effusion without acute middle ear inflammation.  In OME, the TM may be retracted or in a neutral position (not bulging) and appears gray with serous fluid visualized as bubbles or air-fluid levels (
    figure 6
    ).
  • Chronic suppurative otitis media:  Chronic suppurative otitis media is characterized by TM perforation with otorrhea and hearing loss for >6 weeks.
  • Bullous myringitis:  Bullous myringitis is a complication of AOM in which bullae form on the TM.
  • Cholesteatoma:  Cholesteatoma is an abnormal growth of squamous epithelium in the middle ear that presents with hearing loss and a white mass posterior to the TM.

Management

Initial management for AOM may involve initial observation or empiric antibiotic therapy for the most common causal otopathogens (eg, S pneumoniae, nontypeable H influenzae, M catarrhalis).  The choice depends on the patient's risk for severe infection, complications (eg, spread to nearby structures), and recurrence.  Patients at risk for these include:

  • Age <6 months
  • Abnormal craniofacial anatomy
  • Immunocompromised status
  • Septic appearance

For these patients, immediate empiric antibiotic therapy is indicated.  For patients at low risk for severe disease, especially those who are age >2 and have unilateral AOM without severe symptoms (eg, pain >48 hr, temperature >39 C [102.2 F]), initial observation is an option.  If AOM is observed, empiric antibiotic therapy should be initiated if symptoms do not improve within 48-72 hours.

Amoxicillin is effective in most cases of AOM; however, amoxicillin-clavulanic acid should be prescribed in patients at risk for infection with beta-lactamaseâ€“producing nontypeable H influenzae.  Risk factors include:

  • Treatment with amoxicillin within the past 30 days (for AOM or an unrelated diagnosis)
  • AOM with concomitant purulent conjunctivitis (common presentation for nontypeable H influenzae infection)

For patients with severe allergy or adverse reaction to penicillins (eg, anaphylaxis, Stevens-Johnson syndrome), azithromycin or clindamycin are options.

In adults, immediate empiric antibiotic therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is indicated due to the rarity of the condition and the increased risk for complications in this age group.

Complications and prognosis

Empiric antibiotic therapy is effective in most cases.  Although uncommon, potential complications of AOM include:

  • Mastoiditis (
    figure 7
    ):  Because of the close proximity of the mastoid process, direct extension of infection can occur.
  • Facial nerve (CN VII) palsy:  The facial nerve exits from the internal auditory meatus and travels through the middle ear into the mastoid air cells.  Inflammation of the middle ear during an episode of AOM can result in unilateral facial paralysis (
    figure 8
    ).  Common signs include the inability to raise the eyebrow or close the eye, drooping of the corner of the mouth, and disappearance of the nasolabial fold.
  • Meningitis and/or brain abscess (
    Suppurative complications of acute otitis media
    ).

Even with resolution of infection, a middle ear effusion can persist for weeks to months.  Patients with a persistent effusion have OME and require close follow-up and screening for conductive hearing loss.  Tympanostomy tube placement may be considered if a patient has a persistent effusion for >3 months (

figure 10
).  In addition, tympanostomy tube placement may be considered for patients with recurrent treatment failure or â‰¥3 episodes of AOM in 6 months (or â‰¥4 in a year).

Summary

Acute otitis media (
